narratives.question_text:
What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: A History of South Africa taught me the broad themes of South African history. I developed my skills in articulating arguments, interrogating primary sources and writing historical essays.
A deep knowledge of the past several hundred years in South Africa

This was one of the best coursed I've ever taken at Yale. I learned so much, not just about South Africa, but about the history of colonialism and post-colonialism in Africa as well. The readings were incredibly insightful and the class material is great. Highly recommend, even if you arent a history major.
A deeper understanding of the History of South Africa from its pre-colonial state to today.
knowledge into a country i knew nothing about! how to analyze and tie together readings of various formats, from hymns to literature to journal articles

I learned how to do a primary source analysis. I also learned so much about South African history -- I thought this course was specifically going to be focusing on apartheid, but we learned so much more about pre-apartheid era as well as nation-building after apartheid was dismantled. Professor Magaziner is also super engaging and I highly recommend this history course.
I learned a lot about South African history and politics, and definitely improved by reading and writing skills.

This course introduced South African history wonderfullyeach lecture was packed with thought-provoking content, substance, analysis and argumentation. Prof. Magaziner expertly drew out themes central to SA historyIndigeneity, inequality, activism, colonialism, segregationbut also world history. The selection of primary and secondary readings was powerful and some of the best books Ive read this year.

This course covers a history of South Africa, mainly focused on the 19th and 20th centuries. We worked with a variety of primary and secondary courses (one of the paper assignments was a primary source paper) and our readings included works of fictions (e.g. novels), which added an interesting dimension to the course.

I learned about South African history, including some history from as much as a thousand years ago but mostly since the arrival of Europeans (due to preserved writing). Major themes included colonialism, apartheid, land ownership, systems of labor, dispossession, education, and religion.

In addition to learning about the history of South Africa, from indigenous habitation, to colonialism, to mass protest and resilience, I have learned how to become a better history student in this class. Professor Magaziner constantly questioned how we perceive history, as well as the role it plays and the danger it can elicit when it is politicized and manipulated. In South Africa, these questions became particularly pertinent as we studied the Truth and Reconciliation Commission and the task of the post-apartheid state to document, confront, and attempt to reverse and learn from the country's legacy of institutional racism. South Africa is a vital country to study, and it presents telling insights for the United States' own battle against systemic racism and historical revisionism.

How to write primary source analysis + persuasive essay
The importance of student activism and organization
Intersections of race, gender, sexuality, class, etc. in apartheid
The creation of the concept of land ownership, resulting in the displacement and exclusion of Black South Africans
The tools of apartheid and roots in colonial oppression
I gained greater knowledge of South Africa and the effects of apartheid, both when it was happening and today.

narratives.question_text:
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments:
A History of South Africa was well structured to teach several centuries of South African history in a condensed manner. The post-lecture hot takes were a good way to make students engage with the material of each lecture. 

One weakness of the course was that I found several of the readings incredibly difficult to find online. It was difficult to contribute to section a couple weeks because I did not have some of the relevant readings.
Only strengths. Great TAs, great professor, great material, great readings, etc.

strengths: professor magaziner is an engaging lecturer who is a great story teller and emphasizes overarching themes

weakness: class tended to run over
Strengths of this course are Professor Magaziner!!

I loved really every aspect of this course. The lectures were engaging, the papers were flexible so that you could really engage with the material you wanted to in the course. The only thing is I wish there was perhaps secondary sources to help reiterate some of the things we had discussed in lecture. Every week we covered a lot of material and the books that we read for section were fascinating but it would have been great to have some text to help ground/remind us of what we had learned.
This was a fabulous class, I can't recommend it enough. Really, really excellent class.

Strengths: incredibly engaging lectures, highly organized structure/syllabus (helpful for planning ahead), great reading selections (complete with required and suggested readings), great TAs, helpful Q&A breaks during lectures, bi-weekly post-lecture hot-takes that reinforce our understanding/analysis of lectures
Weaknesses: I can hardly think of any... this was an all-around wonderful class. Perhaps it would have been helpful to receive more feedback from Prof. Magaziner on our hot-takes and essays.

Strengths: Professor Magaziner is an excellent lecturer. His storytelling ability makes his lectures engaging and a pleasure to listen to/watch. Additionally, I enjoyed the two writing assignments; both assignments gave enough choice to students to choose an area they wanted to explore more. 

Weaknesses: I would have liked the hot takes to be addressed in section more often. I think there were some interesting points that students brought up that would have made excellent discussion material for section.

The lectures were probably the strongest part of the class. Professor Magaziner delivers lectures that are so clear that he might not even need slides, though (unlike some other history professors) he does have slides, mainly for showing visual components to his lectures. His lectures felt like a story, rather than a list of facts, and it was always easy to pay attention. 

I thought the reading was a little uneven week to week, as some weeks there were many readings and others only had a few.

The strengths were Professor Magaziner's lectures and the wonderful teaching team. The support that we received and the nuanced responses that our instructors gave helped us become better history students in the process of navigating South Africa's complex yet critical story. The hot-takes also helped us work through our thoughts directly after lecture, and provided a fascinating discussion forum for us to engage with our classmates. The weaknesses of this course were not a function of the course, but rather, the product of a busy semester: often, our 50-minute discussion sections felt like too short of a time to properly engage with all of our materials!

Wonderful and engaging lecturer, really well organized 
Recognized that this class is "a" history, not "the" history of South Africa - recognition of biases 
Discussion sections provided a more intimate space to unpack what we learned in class
Slides were very engaging - photos and primary sources integrated were relevant
Interesting and complex readings - appreciated trigger warnings

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments:
The post-lecture hot takes were useful to sustain virtual engagement. 

Sections could have been improved through the use of breakout rooms and other online learning tools.
NA
more flexibility around watching asynchronously

Class over Zoom was as good as it could have been. Definitely slightly less engagement on the students' side than I imagine would have been the case in person, but overall very good adaptation to the COVID online situation.

The virtual lectures were very well conceived, and Prof. Magaziner always uploaded them promptly to Canvas, where full Zoom transcripts could be found (most of the time)this last feature was very helpful for reviewing past lectures and the eloquent quote-worthy statements of Prof. Magaziner. The hot-take requirements also pushed me to think more deeply about lectures amid whirlwind of my other zooms.
I believe the course worked well online, and I am not sure what more could be done to improve the online experience.
I thought the practices geared towards the pandemic specifically were pretty good!

Professor Magaziner's lectures were perfectly suited toward online delivery. Although it was regrettable not to be in the same classroom each week, the lectures transferred well to Zoom. The building in of breaks halfway through and at the end of each lecture also helped rescue some of the lost spontaneous engagement that comes with an in-person semester. Overall, the course was one of my highlights during a difficult online semester!

Very understanding of difficulties during COVID
Flexible with schedule and office hours
Always willing to meet to help out

narratives.question_text:
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Yes! Even over zoom, this was a perfect history lecture. Everything I could want in a survey course: truly exceptional lectures by Prof. Magaziner, diverse and interesting readings, manageable workload and useful assignments, solid discussion sections. And South Africa is one of those countries whose history is everywhere and always relevant, the site of various historical processes with universal resonance and significance. If you love history, please take this course at some point in your Yale career.

I would recommend this course to anyone who is interested in history or in learning about South Africa. The course very effectively covered a number of the factors explaining why South Africa today is the way it is.
If you are interested in this topic, there is no reason not to take this course
yes!! prof magaziner is a great lecturer, and the class was very engaging and well-organized.
YES! Take it. Even if you aren't a History major, it's an amazing course that you need to take before you graduate.
yes i would, great lecture, ties into many broader, international themes - colonialism, race, cold war, etc

Yes! This is the best History lecture I have taken at Yale, and I am History major. Professor Magaziner goes beyond just discussing events and figures like some History lectures and really dives into the cultural movements and intellectual history that influenced South Africa.
Yes! For sure take this, even if you are not a history major.
100 times yes. Please take this class if you have the chance or are considering it. Professor Magaziner is an amazing lecturer. This is my favorite class I have taken at Yale.

Most certainly!! You will not regret itplease take Prof. Magaziner before you leave Yale, whether youre a history major or not. Each lecture is delivered expertly and framed as a story. In this way, even with the vastness of South African history, this courses nuanced history is coherent. The prof. also centers the voices of African South Africans, from artists and writers to activists. Go for it!

Certainly! South African history deals with some important topics: race, colonialism, war, violence, etc. At the same time, one will also learn about the rich cultural history of South/Southern Africa. Additionally, this course gives students opportunities to explore primary sources in an independent manner an important skill to have as a historian (or anyone, for that matter)

Definitely! This is a very approachable history class that is great even for somebody who isn't a history major. The subject matter is really interesting, and contains details relevant not just to South Africa but also many other places. The lectures are interesting even many weeks in, and the sections are pretty good too. The readings are very relevant; the readings for this class were probably the most interesting readings for any class I've been in. There were only two assignments, and they didn't take too long, so the workload (aside from the reading) was very low.

Yes. Professor Magaziner is a wonderful lecturer who went above and beyond to make sure that students had the resources to succeed during the online semester. The material chosen for the course was fascinating and taught masterfully.
definitely

I would absolutely recommend this course to another student. South Africa is a complex yet beyond important country about which to learn. Moreover, Professor Magaziner's lectures effectively encapsulated a myriad of interpretations of the country's story. Never before have I encountered a history course that so fervently tried to analyze the past from every perspective while recognizing the limits of its own scope. Every class is, as Professor Magaziner stated on the first day of the course, "a" history, and his discussions of historiography in the context of South Africa's story were vital discussions for new and veteran history students alike. This class made me a better student and, I hope, a better critical participant of the world. In my opinion, it is a must-take here at Yale.

Yes!! Wonderful and engaging lecturer, really well organized 
Recognized that this class is "a" history, not "the" history of South Africa - recognition of biases 
Discussion sections provided a more intimate space to unpack what we learned in class
Slides were very engaging - photos and primary sources integrated were relevant
Interesting and complex readings - appreciated trigger warnings
Critical to understanding the importance of protest and student activism
Learned how to write primary source analysis + persuasive essay
Intersections of race, gender, sexuality, class, etc. in apartheid
The creation of the concept of land ownership, resulting in the displacement and exclusion of Black South Africans
The tools of apartheid and roots in colonial oppression
Yes, I would recommend this course to anyone interested in history.

narratives.question_text: Please list any other mode(s) of learning, including any combination or variation of the above options.
comments: Twice weekly live virtual lecture (recorded but attendance was strongly encouraged) and once weekly live virtual discussion section.
A History of South Africa had live virtual lectures which were recorded for students in other time zones, and live virtual sections.
Section
NA
virtual section
None.
None.
Discussion section and lecture
We also had a live virtual discussion section
Live virtual discussion section
We also had once a week live virtual section.
We had two live virtual lectures each week, in addition to one synchronous discussion section.
Also included recorded lecture for those who could not make the live virtual lectures
